text: H hi everyone chop the cut here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new one trick
Point never record again this is the
newest fulllength LP from veteran
experimental music producer Daniel o
Patton AKA 10 trick Point never as well
as a bunch of other monikers he's worked
under over the years if you're at all
familiar with the sprawling underbelly
of modern electronic music you either
know Daniel's work or you've heard
something impacted by it be it his plent
ful and Forward Thinking contributions
to the worlds of ambient and drone or
his mind-bending plunder phonics
collages his boundary pushing midi
compositions or even the way he planted
the seeds for much of what we know as
Vapor wave his talents have led him to
transcend into more mainstream circles
on occasion two be it his soundtrack
work for good time or uncut gems plus
his work on the weekend's latest project
Don FM whose radio themed concept seemed
eerily similar to that of Daniel's radio
themed record he put out a few years
prior and speaking of Concepts much of
Daniel's work these days comes with a
methodology or an artistic angle the
cultish and utopian Vibes of 2018s age
of come to mind or the post-industrial
Glitchy deconstructed Rock and pop
Aesthetics that he worked into 2015's
Garden of dele but he seems to be taking
a slightly looser approach with this new
record here a simpler one where Daniel
is looking to the past and revisiting
some key sounds from his back catalog
it's through this he's said to be
collaborating with younger versions of
himself here what's strange though is
this Deja Vu concept is also giving me
Deja Vu because intentional or not I
feel like Daniel kind of already did
this with his last LP magic one of
tricks point never where he again
touched upon a variety of sounds
Concepts and Aesthetics from older
pieces and Records but theatrically
repackaged them in a format that made it
feel like we were kind of traveling
through a bunch of different radio
station broadcasts across the album's
runtime and yeah it feels like we're
back there again we're jumping from idea
to idea and being visited by ghosts from
Daniel's past but once again just like
on the last record I feel like his
catalog is proving to be a little too
big to Encompass in such a project
especially one that's just 13 tracks and
Vapor wave continues to be this dirty
little skeleton he refuses to pull out
of the closet when he's going on these
little retrospective excursions so again
in total on this project we are looking
back but now we don't have this radio
angle in the way like we did on the last
LP so it kind of feels like we're doing
the same thing but with less steps which
pretty much puts me in a place where I
am merely enjoying these songs on the
merits of whether or not they are just
good individually since they're not
being woven together super effectively
on a macro level but that's not
necessarily a bad thing because
thankfully Daniel pops off with a lot of
these exciting and vibrant compositions
with some sneaky appearances here and
there from the likes of shushu and Jim
oor there are some great highlights
throughout the record too like the title
track again which is one of a few
moments on the record that makes me feel
like I'm listening to Daniel's music for
the first time again like in
200920 or having my mind blown by the
replica record for the first time you
have these melting sad drony synth tones
and glitchy bits of static which slow
motion tumbles into this simmer of very
quiet syn layers that feels like it
could gradually get to this point where
it's just gargantuan it's just of
orchestral proportions and it does
eventually reach that Peak we transition
from here into this uh swirling series
of midi voice arpeggios it's engaging
from start to finish and like some of
Daniel's best pieces it's sound
musically while sonically making me feel
like I don't know where the hell I am
half the time which I would also say is
the case for the song the body Trail
which feels like so many disperate parts
of Daniel's repertoire coming together
on one track but under and in between
lots of deep cinematic passages of
string layers meanwhile nightmare paints
guitars and harsh percussion brings back
the gloomiest and darkest bits of Garden
of Delite but maybe now a bit more
harmonious and refined and there are
some pretty surprising progressions on
the tracks plastic antique and lowy in
Midwest too both of which feature
familiar retrofuturistic sounds from
projects like age of and r+ 7 it's like
an idea of what uh this future society's
music would sound like back in 1999 but
now in a way on this new project we're
getting the next artistic step of that
as I think Daniel has had the time and
the hindsight to sort of rethink how he
would approach this sort of thing just
embellishing on it in a way also shout
out to the closer of barely lit path
which is another great moment and I
think actually communicates uh pretty
clearly what this record's real intent
or goal is in a way that's to elevate
some of Daniel's most career-defining
ideas with more musical details and
sometimes these stunning instrumental
layers that are sometimes Han Zimmer
sized in scope the track is really a big
orchestral flex and it works now there
are some cuts and passages on this thing
I'm not that crazy about maybe I feel
like they don't go far enough be that
gray subvol which I think really could
have developed more there's also on an
axis whose very fuzzy slow-mo samples at
the start are like the closest thing we
get to Daniel's Echo jams days but both
feel kind of dwarfed by the other
material here meanwhile elsewhere is a
really cool string piece to kick things
off at the beginning of the album and
while the strings do bring a great
composition there's not really all that
much texturally about them that is super
surreal or colorful which I think is a
pretty key aspect of all the other
tracks on this record that sort of goes
missing here the plotting and lumbering
beats on world outside make this one a
pretty tedious listen even if I do like
the surprise vocal passages that turn up
on this one and speaking of vocal
passages we have the second half of the
track crumbville which morphs into this
really somber lowii Indie Centric
somewhat shoe gazy guitar piece with
some dead pan vocal leads and for sure
I'm surprised something like this is on
the record it is impressive that
Daniel's versatility can take him to
such a place but I can't help but feel
like something along these lines is
below Daniel's talents it feels so
limited and plain and obvious in
comparison with everything else he does
I much prefer the track memories of
Music which also has some pretty
nostalgic and easy to Define
instrumental pallets be it the first leg
of late 9s New Age musac synth stuff
which eventually morphs into these
organs and keys and guitar passages that
have this like vague 60s 7s Rock Fusion
Jam energy going on with some insane and
fiery solo passages too again there are
many moments on this track I mean title
obvious memories of Music uh that are
nostalgic and feel like they're calling
back to the past sounds and Vibes that
are very familiar but Daniel puts his
own weird surreal Twist on all of it uh
that makes it feel specific to this
record so the concept on this one in my
opinion is not as big or as thorough or
as ambitious as past Concepts have been
on many a 10 tricks point Never album un
fortunately but the vast majority of the
material on this thing is still really
good uh by Daniel's General standards
and it is cool to hear him not just kind
of go back and recreate some of these
older sounds but enhance them in a way
so in that respect I would consider this
record a decent W for him even if it's
not one of my all-time favorites he's
ever done I'm feeling a decent to strong
seven on this one TR position have you
given this record a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best you're the best what
should I review next hit the like if you
like Please Subscribe and please don't
cry hit the Bell as well over here next
